sp.p: Mr. Careleſs, If a Perſon that is wholly illiterate might be ſuppoſed to be capable of being qualify'd to make a ſuitable Return to thoſe Obligations which you are pleaſed to confer upon one that is wholly incapable of being qualify'd in all thoſe Circumſtances, I'm ſure I ſhou'd rather attempt it than any thing in the World, [Courteſies.] for I'm ſure there's nothing in the World that I would rather. [Courteſies] But I know Mr. Careleſs is ſo great a Critick and ſo fine a Gentleman, that it is impoſſible for me—

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: O Heav'ns! Madam, you confound me.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Gad's-bud, ſhe's a fine Perſon—

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: O Lord! Sir, pardon me, we Women have not thoſe Advantages: I know my own Imperfections—But at the ſame time you muſt give me leave to declare in the Face of the World that no Body is more ſenſible of Favours and Things; for with the Reſerve of my Honour, I aſſure you, Mr. Careleſs I don't know any thing in the World I would refuſe to a Perſon ſo meritorious—You'll Pardon my want of Expreſſion.—

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: O your Ladyſhip is abounding in all Excellence, particularly that of Phraſe.

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: You are ſo Obliging, Sir.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Your Ladyſhip is ſo Charming.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: So, now, now; now, my Lady.

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: So well bred.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: So ſurprizing.

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: So well dreſt, ſo boon Mein, ſo eloquent, ſo unaffected, ſo eaſie, ſo free, ſo particular, ſo agreeable—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ay, ſo, ſo, there.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: O Lord, I beſeech you, Madam, don't—

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: So gay, ſo graceful, ſo good Teeth, ſo fine Shape, ſo fine Limbs, ſo fine Linnen, and I don't doubt but you have a very good Skin, Sir,

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: For, Heav'ns ſake, Madam—I'm quite out of Countenance.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: And my Lady • s quite out of Breath; you ſhould hear—Gad's-bud, you may talk of my Lady Froth.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: O fie, fie, not to be named of a Day—My Lady Froth is very well in her Accompliſhments—But it is when my Lady Plyant is not thought of—If that can ever be,

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: O you overcome me—That is ſo exceſſive

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Nay, I ſwear and vow that was pretty.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: O Sir Paul, you are the happieſt Man alive. Such a Lady! that is the Envy of her Sex, and the Admiration of ours.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Your humble Servant, I am I thank Heav'n in a fine way of living, as I may ſay, peacefully and happily, and I think need not envy any of my Neighbours, bleſſed be Providence—Ay, truly, Mr. Careleſs, my Lady is a great Bleſſing, a fine, diſcreet, well-ſpoken Woman as you ſhall ſee—If it becomes me to ſay ſo; and we live very comfortably together; ſhe is a little haſty ſometimes, and ſo am I; but mine's ſoon over, and then I'm ſo ſorry—O, Mr. Careleſs, if it were not for one thing—

div.stage: Enter Boy with a Letter, carries it to Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: How often have you been told of that, you Jackanapes?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Gad ſo, gad's-bud—Tim. carry it to my Lady, you ſhould have carry'd it to my Lady firſt.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: 'Tis directed to your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Well, well, my Lady reads all Letters firſt—Child, do ſo no more; d'ye hear Tim.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No, and pleaſe you.
sp.stage: [Carries the Letter to my Lady and Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: A Humour of my Wife's, you know Women have little Fancies—But as I was telling you, Mr. Careleſs, if it were not for one thing, I ſhould think my ſelf the happieſt Man in the World; indeed that touches me near, very near.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: What can that be, Sir Paul?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Why, I have, I thank Heav'n, a very plentiful Fortune, a good Eſtate in the Country, ſome Houſes in Town, and ſome Mony, a pretty tolerable perſonal Eſtate; and it is a great Grief to me, indeed is is, Mr. Careleſs, that I have not a Son to Inherit this—'Tis true, I have a Daughter, and a fine Dutitiful Child ſhe is, though I ſay it, bleſſed be Providence I may ſay; for indeed, Mr. Careleſs, I am mightily beholding to Providence—A poor unworthy Sinner—But if I had a Son, ah, that's my Affliction, and my only Affliction; indeed I cannot refrain Tears when it comes to my Mind •

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p:
Why, methinks th •…
〈…〉 my Lady's a fine likely Woman—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
Oh •
a fine likely Woman as you ſhall ſee in a Summer's
Day—Indeed ſhe is, Mr. Careleſs, in all Reſpects.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: And I ſhould not have taken you to have been ſo old—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Alas, that's not it, Mr. Careleſs; ah! that's not it; no, no, you ſhoot wide of the Mark a Mile; indeed you do, that's not it, Mr. Careleſs; no, no, that's not it.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: No, what can be the Matter then?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: You'll ſcarcely believe me, when I ſhall tell you my Lady is ſo Nice—It's very ſtrange, but it's true: Too true—ſhe's ſo very Nice, that I don't believe ſhe would touch a Man for the World—At leaſt not above once a Year; I'm ſure I have found it ſo; and alas, what's once a Year to an old Man, who would do good in his Generation? Indeed it's true, Mr. Careleſs, it breaks my Heart—I am her Husband, as I may ſay, though far unworthy of that Honour, yet I am her Husband; but alas-a-day, I have no more Familiarity with her Perſon—as to that Matter—than with my own Mother—no indeed.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Alas-a-day, this is a lamentable Story; my Lady muſt be told on't; ſhe muſt i'faith, Sir Paul; 'tis an Injury to the World.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ah! would to Heav'n you would, Mr. Careleſs; you are mightily in her Favour.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: I warrant you, what we muſt have a Son ſome way or other.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Indeed, I ſhould be mightily bound to you, if you could bring it about, Mr. Careleſs.

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: Here, Sir Paul, it's from your Steward, here's a Return of 600 Pounds; you may take Fifty of it for your next half Year.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: How does my Girl? come hither to thy Father, poor Lamb, thou'rt Melancholy.

sp.speaker: Ld. Froth.
sp.p: Heav'n, Sir Paul, you amaze me, of all things in the World—You are never pleas'd but when we are all upon the broad Grin; all Laugh and no Company; ah, then 'tis ſuch a Sight to ſee ſome Teeth—Sure you're a great Admirer of my Lady Whifler, Mr. Sneer, and Sir Laurence Loud, and that Gang.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I vow and ſwear ſhe's a very merry Woman, but, I think ſhe laughs a little too much.

sp.speaker: Ld. Froth.
sp.p:
Merry! O Lord, wh •…
〈…〉 Woman of Quality—You have 〈…〉 Day, Madam?

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Yes my Lord—I muſt 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: O moſt ridiculous, a perpetual Conſort of laughing without any Harmony; for ſure, my Lord, to laugh out of Time, is as diſagreable as to ſing out of Time or out of Tune.

sp.speaker: Ld. F.
sp.p: Hee, hee, hee, right; and then, my Lady Whifler is ſo ready—ſhe always comes in three Bars too ſoon—And then, what do they laugh at? For you know laughing without a Jeſt is as impertinent; hee! as, as—

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: As Dancing without a Fiddle.

sp.speaker: Ld. F.
sp.p: Juſt 'ifaith, that was at my Tongue's end.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: But that cannot be properly ſaid of them, for I think they are all in good Nature with the World, and only Laugh at one another; and you muſt allow they have all Jeſts in their Perſons, though they have none in their Converſation.

sp.speaker: Ld. F.
sp.p: True, as I'm a Perſon of Honour—For Heav'ns ſake let us ſacriſice 'em to Mirth a little.

div.stage: Enter Boy and whiſpers Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: 'Gads ſo—Wife, Wife, my Lady Plyant, I have a Word.

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: I'm buſie, Sir Paul, I wonder at your Impertinence—

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Sir Paul, harkee, I'm reaſoning the Matter you know; Madam,—if your Ladyſhip pleaſe, we'll diſcourſe of this in the next Room.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: O ho, I wiſh you good Succeſs, I wiſh you good Succeſs. Boy, tell my Lady, when ſhe has done, I would ſpeak with her below.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: Then you think that Epiſode between Suſan, the Dairy-Maid, and our Coach-man is not amiſs; you know, I may ſuppoſe the Dairy in Town, as well as in the Country.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Incomparable, let me periſh—But then being an Heroick Poem, had not you better call him a Charioteer? Charioteer ſounds great; beſides your Ladyſhip's Coachman having a red Face, and you comparing him to the Sun—And you know the Sun is call'd Heav'ns Charioteer.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: Oh, infinitely better; I'm extreamly beholding to you for the Hint; ſtay, we'll read over thoſe half a Score Lines again. [Pulls out a Paper.] Let me ſee here, you know what goes before, the Compariſon, you know.
sp.l: For as the Sun ſhines ev'ry Day,
So of our Coach-man I may ſay.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: I'm afraid that Simile won't do in wet Weather—Becauſe you ſay the Sun ſhines ev'ry Day •

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: No, for the Sun is won't, but it will do for the Coachman, for you know there's moſt Occaſion for a Coach in wet Weather.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Right, right, that ſaves all.

sp.speaker: L F.
sp.p: Then I don't ſay the Sun ſhines all the Day, but that he peeps now and then, yet he does ſhine all the Day too, you know, tho' we don't ſee him.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Right, but the Vulgar will never comprehend that.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: Well, you ſhall here—Let me ſee.
sp.l: For as the Sun ſhines ev'ry Day,
So, of our Coach-man I may ſay,
He ſhows his drunken fiery Face,
Juſt as the Sun does, more or leſs.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: That's right, all's well, all's well.

sp.l: And when at Night his Labour's done,
Then too, like Heav'ns Charioteer, the Sun:

sp.p: Ay, Charioteer does better.

sp.l: Into the Dairy he deſcends,
And there his Whipping and his Driving ends;
There he's ſecure from Danger of a Bilk,
His Fare is paid him, and he ſets in Milk.

sp.p: For Suſan, you know, is Thetis, and ſo—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Incomparable well and proper, Igad—But I have one Exception to make—Don't you think Bilk (I know its good Rhime) but don't you think Bilk and Fare too like a Hackney Coach-man?

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: I ſwear and vow I'm afraid ſo—And yet our Jehu was a Hackney Coach-man, when my Lord took him.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Was that he then, I'm anſwer'd, if Jehu was a Hackney Coach-man—You may put that in the marginal Notes tho', to prevent Criticiſm—Only mark it with a ſmall Aſteriſm, and ſay,—Jehu was formerly a Hackney Coach-man.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: I will; you'd oblige me extremely to write Notes to the whole Poem.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: With all my Heart and Soul, and proud of the vaſt Honour, let me periſh.

sp.speaker: Ld. F.
sp.p: Hee, hee, hee, my Dear, have you done—won't you join with us, we were laughing at my Lady Whifler, and Mr. Sneer.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: —Ay my Dear—Were you? Oh filthy Mr. Sneer; he's a nauſeous Figure, a moſt fulſmick Fop, Foh—He ſpent Two Days together in going about Covent-Garden to ſuit the Lining of his Coach with his Complexion.

sp.speaker: Ld. F.
sp.p: O ſilly! yet his Aunt is as fond of him, as if ſhe had brought the Ape into the World her ſelf.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Who, my Lady Toothleſs; O, ſhe's a mortifying Spectacle; ſhe's always chewing the Cud like an old Yew.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Fie, Mr. Brisk, 'tis Eringo's for her Cough.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: I have ſeen her take 'em half chew'd out of her Mouth, to laugh, and then put 'em in again—Foh.

sp.speaker: Ld. F.
sp.p: Foh.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: Then ſhe's always ready to laugh when Sneer offers to ſpeak—And ſits in Expectation of his no Jeſt, with her Gums bare, and her Mouth open—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Like an Oyſter at low Ebb, I'gad—Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Well, I find there are no Fools ſo inconſiderable in themſelves, but they can render other People contemptible in expoſing their Infirmities.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: Then that t'other great ſtrapping Lady—I can't hit of her Name; the old fat Fool that Paints ſo exorbitantly.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: I know whom you mean—But Deuce take me I can't hit of her Name neither—Paints d'ye ſay? Why ſhe lays it on with a Trowel—Then ſhe has a great Beard that briſtles through it, and makes her look as if ſhe were plaiſter'd with Lime and Hair, let me periſh.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: Oh you made a Song upon her, Mr. Brisk.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: He? e'gad, ſo I did—My Lord can ſing it.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: O good my Lord let's hear it.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: 'Tis not a Song neither—It's a ſort of an Epigram, or rather an Epigrammatick Sonnet; I don't know what to call it, but it's Satire.—Sing it my Lord.

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: Ancient Phillis, has young Graces,
'Tis a ſtrange thing, but a true one;
Shall I tell you how?
She her ſelf makes her own Faces,
And each Morning wears a new one;
Where's the Wonder now?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Short, but there's Salt in't; my way of Writing I'gad.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Your Ladyſhip's Chair is come.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: Is Nurſe and the Child in it?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: O the dear Creature! Let's go ſee it.

sp.speaker: Ld F.
sp.p: I ſwear, my Dear, you'll ſpoil that Child, with ſending it to and again ſo often, this is the Seventh Time the Chair has gone for her to Day.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: O-law, I ſwear it's but the Sixth,—and I han't ſeen her theſe two Hours—The poor dear Creature—I ſwear, my Lord, you don't Love poor little Sapho—Come, my dear Cynthia, Mr. Brisk, we'll go ſee Sapho, tho' my Lord won't

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: I'll wait upon your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, how old is Lady Sapho?

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: Three Quarters, but I ſwear ſhe has a World of Wit, and can ſing a Tune already? My Lord, won't you go? Won't you? What not to ſee Saph? Pray, my Lord, come ſee little Saph. I knew you cou'd not ſtay.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Tis not ſo hard to counterfeit Joy in the depth of Affliction, as to diſſemble Mirth in Company of Fools—Why ſhould I call 'em Fools? The World thinks better of 'em; for theſe have Quality and Education, Wit and fine Converſation, are receiv'd and admir'd by the World—If not, they like and admire themſelves—And why is not that true Wiſdom, for 'tis Happineſs: And for ought I know, we have miſapply'd the Name all this while, and miſtaken the Thing: Since
sp.l: If Happineſs in Self-content is plac'd,
The Wiſe are Wretched, and Fools only Bleſs'd.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: ACT IV. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: I Heard him loud as I came by the Cloſet-Door, and my Lady with him, but ſhe ſeem'd to moderate his Paſſion.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Ay, Hell thank her, as gentle Breezes moderate a Fire; but I ſhall counter-work her Spells, and ride the Witch in her own Bridle.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: It's impoſſible, ſhe'll caſt beyond you ſtill—I'll lay my Life it will never be a Match.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Between you and me.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: My Mind gives me it won't—becauſe we are both willing; we each of us ſtrive to reach the Gole, and hinder one another in the Race; I ſwear it never do's well when the Parties are ſo agreed—For when People walk Hand in Hand, there's neither overtaking nor meeting: We Hunt in Couples where we both purſue the ſame Game, but forget one another; and 'tis becauſe we are ſo near that we don't think of coming together.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Hum, 'gad I believe there's ſomething in't;—Marriage is the Game that we Hunt, and while we think that we only have it in View, I don't ſee but we have it in our Power,

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Within reach; for Example, give me your Hand; why have you look'd through the wrong End of the Perſpective all this while; for nothing has been between us but our Fears.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I don't know why we ſhould not ſteal out of the Houſe this Moment and Marry one another, without Conſideration or the Fear of Repentance. Pox o'Fortune, Portion; Settlements and Jointures.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Ay, ay, what have we to do with 'em; you know we Marry for Love.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Love, Love, down-right very Villainous Love.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: And he that can't live upon Love, deſerves to die in a Ditch.—Here then, I give you my Promiſe, in ſpight of Duty, any Temptation of Wealth, your Inconſtancy, or my own Inclination to change—

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: To run moſt wilfully and unreaſonably away with me this Moment, and be Married.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Hold—Never to Marry any Body elſe.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: That's but a kind of Negative Conſent.—Why, you won't baulk the Frolick?

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: If you had not been ſo aſſured of your own Conduct I would not—But 'tis but reaſonable that ſince I conſent to like a Man without the vile Conſideration of Mony, he ſhould give me a very evident Demonſtration of his Wit: Therefore let me ſee you undermine my Lady Touchwood, as you boaſted, and force her to give her Conſent, and then—

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I'll do't.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: And I'll do't.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: This very next enſuing Hour of Eight a Clock, is the laſt Minute of her Reign, unleſs the Devil aſſiſt her in propria perſona.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Well, if the Devil ſhould aſſiſt her, and your Plot miſcarry.—

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Ay, what am I to truſt to then?

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Why if you give me very clear demonſtration that it was the Devil, I'll allow for irreſiſtable odds. But if I find it to be only Chance, or Deſtiny, or unlucky Stars, or any thing but the very Devil, I'm inexorable: Only ſtill I'll keep my Word, and live a Maid for your ſake.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: And you won't die one, for your own, ſo ſtill there's Hope.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Here's my Mother-in-Law, and your Friend Careleſs, I would not have 'em ſee us together yet.

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: I ſwear, Mr. Careleſs, you are very alluring—And ſo many fine Things, and nothing is ſo moving to me as a fine Thing. Well, I muſt do you this Juſtice, and declare in the Face of the World, never any Body gain'd ſo far upon me as your ſelf; with Bluſhes I muſt own it, you have ſhaken, as I may ſay, the very Foundation of my Honour—Well, ſure if I eſcape your Importunities, I ſhall value my ſelf as long as I live, I ſwear.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: And Deſpiſe me. (Sighing.)

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: The laſt of any Man in the World, by my Purity; now you make me ſwear—O Gratitude forbid, that I ſhould ever be wanting in a reſpectful Acknowledgment of an intire Reſignation of all my beſt Wiſhes, for the Perſon and Parts of ſo accompliſh'd a Perſon, whoſe Merit challenges much more, I'm ſure, than my illiterate Praiſes can deſcription;

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: (In a whining Tone.) Ah Heav'ns, Madam, you ruin me with Kindneſs; your Charming Tongue purſues the Victory of your Eyes, while at your Feet your poor Adorer dies.

sp.speaker: L P.
sp.p: Ah! Very fine.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: (Still whining.) Ah why are you ſo Fair, ſo bewitching Fair? O let me grow to the Ground here, and feaſt upon that Hand; O let me preſs it to my Heart, my trembling Heart, the nimble Movement ſhall inſtruct your Pulſe, and teach it to allarm Deſire.
[Zoons I'm almoſt at the end of my Cant, if ſhe does not yield quickly. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: L P.
sp.p: O that's ſo paſſionate and fine, I cannot hear it—I am not ſafe if I ſtay, and muſt leave you.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: And muſt you leave me! Rather let me languiſh out a Wretched Life, and breath my Soul beneath your Feet.
[I muſt ſay the ſame Thing over again, and can't help it. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: I ſwear I am ready to languiſh too—O my Honour! Whither is it going? I proteſt you have given me the Palpitation of the Heart.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Can you be ſo cruel.—

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: O riſe I beſeech you, ſay no more 'till you riſe—Why did you kneel ſo long? I ſwear I was ſo tranſported, I did not ſee it.—Well, to ſhew you how far you have gain'd upon me; I aſſure you if Sir Paul ſhould die, of all Mankind there's none I'd ſooner make my ſecond Choice.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: O Heav'n! I can't out live this Night without your Favour—I feel my Spirits faint, a general Dampneſs overſpreads my Face, a cold deadly Dew already vents through all my Pores, and will to Morrow waſh me for ever from your Sight, and drown me in my Tomb.

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: O you have Conquer'd, ſweet, melting, moving Sir, you have Conquer'd—What Heart of Marble can refrain to Weep, and yield to ſuch ſad Sayings.—

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: I thank Heav'n, they are the ſaddeſt that I ever ſaid—Oh!
[I ſhall never contain Laughter. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: Oh, I yield my ſelf all up to your uncontroulable Embraces—Say, thou dear dying Man, when, where, and how.—Ah, there's Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: 'Slife, yonder's Sir Paul, but if he were not come, I'm ſo tranſported I cannot ſpeak—This Note will inform you.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Thou art my tender Lambkin, and ſhalt do what thou wilt—But endeavour to forget this Mellefont.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: I would obey you to my Power, Sir; but if I have not him, I have ſworn never to Marry.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Never to Marry! Heav'ns forbid; muſt I neither have Sons nor Grandſons? muſt the Family of the Plyants be utterly extinct for want of Iſſue Male. Oh Impiety! But did you ſwear, did that ſweet Creature ſwear! ha? How durſt you ſwear without my Conſent, ah? Gads-bud, who am I?

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Pray don't be angry, Sir, when I ſwore, I had your Conſent, and therefore I ſwore.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Why then the revoking my Conſent does annul, or make of none effect your Oath: So you may unſwear it again 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Ay, but my Conſcience never will.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Gads-bud no matter for that, Conſcience and Law never go together; you muſt not expect that.

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: Ay, but Sir Paul, I conceive if ſhe has ſworn, d'ye mark me, if ſhe has once ſworn; it is moſt unchriſtian, inhuman, and obſcene that ſhe ſhou'd break it.—I'll make up the Match again, becauſe Mr. Careleſs ſaid it would oblige him. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Does your Ladyſhip conceive ſo—Why I was of that Opinion once too—Nay if your Ladyſhip conceives ſo, I'm of that Opinion again; but I can neither find my Lord and my Lady to know what they intend.

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: I'm ſatisfied that my Couſin Mellefont has been much wrong'd.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: (Aſide.) I'm amazed to find her of our ſide, for I'm ſure ſhe lov'd him.

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: I know my Lady Touchwood has no Kindneſs for him; and beſides I have been inform'd by Mr. Careleſs, that Mellefont had never any thing more than a profound Reſpect—That he has own'd himſelf to be my Admirer 'tis true, but he was never ſo preſumptuous to entertain any diſhonourable Notions of Things; ſo that if this be made plain—I don't ſee how my Daughter can in Conſcience, or Honour, or any thing in the World—

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Indeed if this be made plain, as my Lady your Mother ſays, Child—

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: Plain! I was inform'd of it by Mr. Careleſs—And I aſſure you Mr. Careleſs is a Perſon—that has a moſt extraordinary Reſpect and Honour for you, Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: (Aſide.) And for your Ladyſhip too, I believe, or elſe you had not chang'd Sides ſo ſoon; now I begin to find it.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: I am much obliged to Mr. Careleſs really, he is a Perſon that I have a great Value for, not only for that, but becauſe he has a great Veneration for your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: O las, no indeed, Sir Paul, 'tis upon your Account.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: No I proteſt and vow, I have no Title to his Eſteem, but in having the Honour to appertain in ſome meaſure to your Ladyſhip, that's all.

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: O law now, I ſwear and declare, it ſhan't be ſo, you're too modeſt, Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: It becomes me, when there is any Compariſon made, between—

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: O fy, fy, Sir Paul, you'll put me out of Countenance—Your very obedient and affectionate Wife; that's all—And highly honoured in that Title.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Gads-bud I am tranſported! Give me leave to kiſs your Ladyſhip's Hand.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: That my poor Father ſhould be ſo very ſilly! [Aſide.

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: My Lip indeed, Sir Paul, I ſwear you ſhall.
sp.stage: [He kiſſes her, and bows very low.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I humbly thank your Ladyſhip—I don't know whether I fly on Ground, or walk in Air—Gads-bud, ſhe was never thus before—Well, I muſt own my ſelf the moſt beholden to Mr. Careleſs—As ſure as can be this is all his doing,—ſomething that he has ſaid; well, 'tis a rare thing to have an Ingenious Friend. Well, your Ladyſhip is of Opinion that the Match may go forward.

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: By all means—Mr. Careleſs has ſatisfy'd me of the Matter.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Well, why then Lamb you may keep your Oath, but have a care of making raſh Vows; come hither to me, and kiſs Papa.

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: I ſwear and declare, I am in ſuch a twitter to read Mr. Careleſs his Letter, that I can't forbear any longer—But though I may read all Letters firſt by Prerogative, yet I'll be ſure to be unſuſpected this time.—Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Did your Ladyſhip call?

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: Nay, not to interrupt you my Dear—Only lend me your Letter, which you had from your Steward to Day: I would look upon the Account again; and may be increaſe your Allowance.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: There it is, Madam; Do you want a Pen and Ink?

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: No, no, nothing elſe, I thank you, Sir Paul.—So now I can read my own Letter under the cover of his. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: He? And wilt thou bring a Grandſon at nine Months end—He? A brave chopping Boy.—I'll ſettle a Thouſand Pound a Year upon the Rogue as ſoon as ever he looks me in the Face, I will Gads-bud. I'm overjoy'd to think I have any of my Family that will bring Children into the World. For I would fain have ſome Reſemblance of my ſelf in my Poſterity, he Thy? Can't you contrive that affair Girl? Do gads-bud, think on thy old Father; Heh? Make the young Rogue as like as you can.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: I'm glad to ſee you ſo merry, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
Merry, Gads-bud I'm ſerious, I'll give thee 500l. for every Inch of him that reſembles me; ah this Eye, this Left Eye!
A Thouſand Pound for this Left Eye. This has done Execution in its time Girl; why thou haſt my Leer Huſſey, juſt thy Father's Leer.—Let it be tranſmitted to the young Rogue by the help of Imagination; why 'tis the Mark of our Family Thy; our Houſe is diſtinguiſh'd by a languiſhing Eye, as the Houſe of Auſtria is by a thick Lip.—Ah! when I was of your Age Huſſey, I would have held fifty to one, I could have drawn my own Picture—Gads-bud I could have done—not ſo much as you neither,—but—nay, don't bluſh—

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: I don't bluſh, Sir, for I vow I don't underſtand.—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Pſhaw, Pſhaw, you fib you Baggage, you do underſtand, and you ſhall underſtand; come don't be ſo nice, Gads-bud don't learn after your Mother-in-Law my Lady here: Marry Heaven forbid that you ſhould follow her Example, that would ſpoil all indeed. Bleſs us, if you ſhould take a Vagarie and make a raſh Reſolution on your Wedding Night, to die a Maid, as ſhe did; all were ruin'd, all my Hopes loſt—My Heart would break, and my Eſtate would be left to the wide World, he? I hope you are a better Chriſtian than to think of living a Nun; he? Anſwer me?

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: I'm all Obedience, Sir, to your Commands.

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: [Having read the Letter) O dear Mr. Careleſs, I ſwear he writes charmingly, and he talks charmingly, and he looks charmingly, and he has charm'd me, as much as I have charm'd him; and ſo I'll tell him in the Wardrobe when 'tis Dark. O Crimine! I hope Sir Paul has not ſeen both Letters.
sp.stage: [Puts the wrong Letter haſtily up, and gives him her own.
sp.p: Sir Paul, here's your Letter, to Morrow Morning I'll ſettle the Accounts to your Advantage.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Sir Paul, Gads-bud you're an uncivil Perſon, let me tell you, and all that; and I did not think it had been in you.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: O Law, what's the matter now? I hope you are not angry, Mr. Brisk.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Deuce take me I believe you intend to Marry your Daughter your ſelf; you're always brooding over her like an old Hen, as if ſhe were not well hatch'd, I'gad, he?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Good ſtrange! Mr. Brisk is ſuch a Merry Facetious Perſon, he, he, he. No, no, I have done with her, I have done with her now.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: The Fiddlers have ſtay'd this Hour in the Hall, and my Lord Froth wants a Partner, we can never begin without her.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Go, go Child, go, get you gone and Dance and be Merry, I'll come and look at you by and by.—Where's my Son Mellefont?

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: I'll ſend him to them, I know where he is.—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Sir Paul, will you ſend Careleſs into the Hall if you meet him.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: I will, I will, I'll go and look for him on purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: So now they are all gone, and I have an Opportunity to practiſe.—Ah! My dear Lady Froth! She's a moſt engaging Creature, if ſhe were not ſo fond of that damn'd coxcombly Lord of hers; and yet I am forced to allow him Wit too, to keep in with him—No matter, ſhe's a Woman of Parts, and I'gad Parts will carry her. She ſaid ſhe would follow me into the Gallery—Now to make my Approaches—Hem hem! Ah Ma- (Bows.) dam!—Pox on't, why ſhould I diſparage my Parts by thinking what to ſay? None but dull Rogues think; witty Men, like rich Fellows, are always ready for all Expences; while your Blockheads, like poor needy Scoundrels, are forced to examine their Stock, and forecaſt the Charges of the Day. Here ſhe comes, I'll ſeem not to ſee her, and try to win her with a new airy Invention of my own, hem!
I'm ſick with Love, ha, ha, ha, prithee come cure walking about. me. I'm ſick with, &c.
O ye Powers! O my Lady Froth, my Lady Froth! My Lady Froth! Heigho! Break Heart; God's I thank you.

sp.speaker: L. Froth.
sp.p: O Heav'ns, Mr. Brisk! What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: My Lady Froth! Your Ladyſhip's moſt humble Servant;—The matter, Madam? Nothing, Madam, nothing at all I'gad. I was fallen into the moſt agreeable Amuſement in the whole Province of Contemplation: That's all—
(I'll ſeem to conceal my Paſſion, and that will look like Reſpect.) [Aſide.

sp.speaker: L. Froth.
sp.p: Bleſs me, why did you call out upon me ſo loud?—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: O Lord I Madam! I beſeech your Ladyſhip—when?

sp.speaker: L. Froth.
sp.p: Juſt now as I came in, bleſs me, why don't you know it?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Not I, let me periſh—But did I! Strange! I confeſs your Ladyſhip was in my Thoughts; and I was in a ſort of Dream that did in a manner repreſent a very pleaſing Object to my Imagination, but—but did I indeed?—To ſee how Love and Murder will out. But did I really name my Lady Froth?

sp.speaker: L. Froth.
sp.p: Three times aloud, as I love Letters—But did you talk of Love? O Parnaſſus! Who would have thought Mr. Brisk could have been in Love, ha, ha, ha. O Heav'ns I thought you cou'd have no Miſtreſs but the Nine Muſes.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: No more I have I'gad, for I adore 'em all in your Ladyſhip—Let me periſh, I don't know whether to be ſplenatick, or Airy upon't; the Deuce take me if I can tell whether I am glad or ſorry that your Ladyſhip has made the Diſcovery.

sp.speaker: L. Froth.
sp.p: O be merry by all means—Prince Volſcius in Love! Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: O barbarous, to turn me into Ridicule! Yet, ha, ha, ha. The Deuce take me, I can't help Laughing my ſelf, ha, ha, ha; yet by Heav'ns I have a violent Paſſion for your Ladyſhip, ſeriouſly.

sp.speaker: L. Froth.
sp.p: Seriouſly? Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Seriouſly, ha, ha, ha. Gad I have, for all I laugh.

sp.speaker: L. Froth.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! What d'ye think I laugh at? Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Me I'gad, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: L. Froth.
sp.p: No the Deuce take me if I don't Laugh at my ſelf; for hang me if I have not a violent Paſſion for Mr. Brisk, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Seriouſly?

sp.speaker: L. Froth.
sp.p: Seriouſly, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: That's well enough; let me periſh, ha, ha, ha. O Miraculous, what a happy Diſcovery. Ah my dear charming Lady Froth!

sp.speaker: L. Froth.
sp.p: Oh my adored Mr. Brisk!

sp.speaker: Ld. Froth.
sp.p: The Company are all ready—How now!

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Zoons, Madam, there's my Lord. [Softly to her.

sp.speaker: L. Froth.
sp.p: Take no notice—but obſerve me—Now caſt off, and meet me at the lower end of the Room, and then join Hands again; I could teach my Lord this Dance purely, but I vow, Mr. Brisk, I can't tell how to come ſo near any other Man. Oh here's my Lord, now you ſhall ſee me do it with him.
sp.stage: [They pretend to practiſe part of a Country Dance.

sp.speaker: Ld. Froth.
sp.p: —Oh I ſee there's no harm yet—But I don't like this Familiarity [Aſide.

sp.speaker: L. Froth.
sp.p: —Shall you and I do our cloſe Dance, to ſhow Mr. Brisk,

sp.speaker: Ld. Froth.
sp.p: No, my Dear, do it with him.

sp.speaker: L. Froth.
sp.p: I'll do it with him, my Lord, when you are out of the way.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: That's good I'gad, that's good • Deuce take me I can 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Ld. Froth.
sp.p: Any other time, my Dear, or we'll dance it below.

sp.speaker: L. Froth.
sp.p: With all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Come my Lord, I'll wait on you—My charming witty Angel! [To her

sp.speaker: L. Froth.
sp.p: We ſhall have whiſpering time enough, you know, ſince we are Partners.

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: O Mr. Careleſs, Mr. Careleſs, I'm ruin'd, I'm undone.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: What's the matter, Madam?

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: O the unlucky'ſt Accident, I'm afraid I ſhan't live to tell it you.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Heav'n forbid! What is it?

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: I'm in ſuch a Fright; the ſtrangeſt Quandary and Premunire! I'm all over in a Univerſal Agitation, I dare ſwear every Circumſtance of me trembles.—O your Letter, your Letter! By an unfortunate Miſtake, I have given Sir Paul your Letter inſtead of his own.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: That was unlucky.

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: O yonder he comes reading of it, for Heav'ns ſake ſtep in here and adviſe me quickly, before he ſees.

div.stage: Enter Sir Paul with the Letter.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: —O Providence, what a Conſpiracy have I diſcover'd—But let me ſee to make an end on't.— (Reads) Hum—After Supper in the Wardrobe by the Gallery. If Sir Paul ſhould ſurprize us, I have a Commiſſion from him to treat with you about the very matter of Fact.—Matter of Fact! Very pretty; it ſeems then I am conducing to my own Cuckoldom; why this is the very traiterous Poſition of taking up Arms by my Authority, againſt my Perſon! Well, let me ſee—'Till then I languiſh in expectation of my Adored Charmer.

Gads-bud, would that were matter of Fact too. Die and be Damn'd for a Judas Maccabeus, and Iſcariot both. O Friendſhip! What art thou but a Name! Henceforward let no Man make a Friend that would not be Cuckold: For whomſoever he receives into his Boſom, will find the Way to his Bed, and there return his Careſſes with Intereſt to his Wife. Have I for this been pinion'd Night after Night for three Years paſt? Have I been ſwath'd in Blankets 'till I have been even depriv'd of Motion, and render'd uncapable of uſing the common Benefits of Nature? Have I approach'd the Marriage Bed with Reverence as to a ſacred Shrine, and deny'd my ſelf the Enjoyment of lawful Domeſtick
Pleaſures to preſerve its Purity, and muſt I now find it polluted by foreign Iniquity? O my Lady Plyant, you were chaſte as Ice, but you are melted now, and falſe as Water.—But Providence has been conſtant to me in diſcovering this Conſpiracy; ſtill I am beholden to Providence, if it were not for Providence, ſure poor Sir Paul thy Heart would break.

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: So, Sir, I ſee you have read the Letter,—Well now, Sir Paul, what do you think of your Friend Careleſs? Has he been Treacherous, or did you give his Inſolence a Licenſe to make Trial of your Wife's ſuſpected Virtue? D'ye ſee here?

Look, read it? Gad's my Life if I thought it were ſo, I would this Moment renounce all Communication with you. Ungrateful Monſter! He? Is it ſo? Ay, I ſee it, a Plot upon my Honour; your guilty Cheeks confeſs it: Oh where ſhall wrong'd Virtue fly for Reparation! I'll be divorced this Inſtant.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Gads-bud, what ſhall I ſay? This is the ſtrangeſt Surprize! Why I don't know any thing at all, nor I don't know whether there be any thing at all in the World, or no,

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: I thought I ſhould try you, falſe Man. I that never diſſembled in my Life: Yet to make trial of you, pretended to like that Monſter of Iniquity, Careleſs, and found out that Contrivance to let you ſee this Letter; which now I find was of your own inditing—I do Heathen, I do; ſee my Face no more; there has hardly been Conſummation between us, and I'll be divorced preſently.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: O ſtrange, what will become of me!—I'm ſo amaz'd, and ſo overjoy'd, ſo afraid, and ſo ſorry.—But did you give me this Letter on purpoſe, he? Did you?

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: Did I? Do you doubt me, Turk, Sarazen? I have a Couſin that's a Proctor in the Commons, I'll go to him inſtantly.—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Hold, ſtay, I beſeech your Ladyſhip—I'm ſo overjoy'd, ſtay, I'll confeſs all.

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: What will you confeſs, Jew?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Why now as I hope to be ſav'd, I had no Hand in this Letter—Nay hear me, I beſeech your Ladyſhip: The Devil take me now if he did not go beyond my Commiſſion—If I deſired him to do any more than ſpeak a good Word only juſt for me; Gads-bud only for poor Sir Paul, I'm an Anabaptiſt, or a Jew, or what you pleaſe to call me.

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: Why is not here matter of Fact?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ay, but by your own Virtue and Continency that matter of Fact is all his own doing.—I confeſs I had a great Deſire to have ſome Honours conferr'd upon me, which lye all in your Ladyſhip's Breaſt, and he being a well-ſpoken Man, I deſired him to intercede for me.—

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: Did you ſo, Preſumption! Well, remember for this, your right Hand ſhall be ſwath'd down again to Night—And I thought to have always allow'd you that Liberty.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Nay but Madam, I ſhall offend again if you do not allow me that to reach—

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: Drink the leſs you Sot, and do't before you come to Bed.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Sir Paul, I'm glad I've met with you, 'gad I have ſaid all I could, but can't prevail—Then my Friendſhip to you has carried me a little farther in this Matter—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Indeed—Well Sir—I'll diſſemble with him a little. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Why faith I have in my Time known honeſt Gentlemen abuſed by a pretended Coyneſs in their Wives, and I had a mind to try my Lady's Virtue—And when I could not prevail for you, 'gad I pretended to be in Love my ſelf—but all in vain, ſhe would not hear a Word upon that Subject: Then I Writ a Letter to her; I don't know what Effects that will have, but I'll be ſure to tell you when I do, tho' by this Light I believe her Virtue is impregnable.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: O Providence! Providence! What Diſcoveries are here made? Why, this is better and more Miraculous than the reſt.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I can't tell you, I'm ſo overjoy'd; come along with me to my Lady, I can't contain my ſelf; come my dear Friend.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: So, ſo, ſo, this Difficulty's over. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Maskwell! I have been looking for you—'tis within a Quarter of Eight.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: My Lady is juſt gone into my Lord's Cloſet, you had beſt ſteal into her Chamber before ſhe comes, and lye concealed there, otherwiſe ſhe may Lock the Door when we are together, and you not eaſily get in to ſurprize us.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: He? You ſay true.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: You had beſt make haſte, for ſhe's gone to make ſome 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I go this Moment: Now Fortune I defie thee.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I confeſs you may be allow'd to be ſecure in your own Opinion; the Appearance is very fair, but I have an After Game to play that ſhall turn the Tables, and here comes the Man that I muſt manage.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Maskwell, you are the Man I wiſh'd to meet.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I am happy to be in the way of your Lordſhip's Commands.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: I have always found you prudent and careful in any thing that has concern'd me or my Family.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I were a Villain elſe—I am bound by Duty and Gratitude, and my own Inclination, to be ever your Lordſhip's Servant.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Enough—You are my Friend; I know it: Yet there has been a thing in your Knowledge, which has concern'd me nearly, that you have conceal'd from me.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Nay, I excuſe your Friendſhip to my unnatural Nephew thus far—But I know you have been Privy to his impious Deſigns upon my Wife. This Ev'ning ſhe has told me all: Her good Nature conceal'd it as long as was poſſible; but he perſeveres ſo in Villany, that ſhe has told me even you were weary of diſſuading him, though you have once actually hindered him from forcing her.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I am ſorry, my Lord, I can't make you an Anſwer; this is an Occaſion in which I would not willingly be ſo ſilent.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: I know you would excuſe him—And I know as well that you can't.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Indeed I was in hopes 'thad been a youthful Heat that might have ſoon boil'd over; but—

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Say on.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I have nothing more to ſay, my Lord—But to expreſs my Concern; for I think his Frenzy increaſes daily.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: How! Give me but Proof of it, Ocular Proof, that I may juſtifie my Dealing with him to the World, and ſhare my Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: O my Lord! conſider that is hard: Beſides, time may work upon him: Then, for me to do it! I have profeſs'd an everlaſting Friendſhip to him.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: He is your Friend, and what am I?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I am anſwered.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Fear not his Diſpleaſure; I will put you out of his, and Fortune's Power, and for that thou art ſcrupulouſly honeſt, I will ſecure thy Fidelity to him, and give my Honour never to own any Diſcovery that you ſhall make me. Can you give me a demonſtrative Proof? Speak.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I wiſh I could not—To be plain, my Lord, I intended this Ev'ning to have try'd all Arguments to diſſuade him from a Deſign, which I ſuſpect; and if I had not ſucceeded, to have informed your Lordſhip of what I knew.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: I thank you. What is the Villain's Purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: He has own'd nothing to me of late, and what I mean now, is only a bare Suſpicion of my own. If your Lordſhip will meet me a Quarter of an Hour hence there, in that Lobby by my Lady's Bed-Chamber, I ſhall be able to tell you more.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: My Duty to your Lordſhip, makes me do a ſevere Piece of Juſtice.—

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: I will be ſecret, and reward your Honeſty beyond your Hopes.

div.stage: SCENE opening ſhews Lady Touchwood's Chamber. Mellefont Solus.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Pray Heav'n my Aunt keep touch with her Aſſignation.—Oh that her Lord were but ſweating behind this Hanging, with the Expectation of what I ſhall ſee—Hiſt, ſhe comes—Little does ſhe think what a Mine is juſt ready to ſpring under her Feet. But to my Poſt.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: 'Tis Eight a Clock: Methinks I ſhould have found him here. Who does not prevent the Hour of Love, outſtays the Time; for to be dully punctual, is too ſlow.—I was accuſing you of Neglect.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I confeſs you do reproach me when I ſee you here before me; but 'tis fit I ſhould be ſtill behind hand, ſtill to be more and more indebted to your Goodneſs.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: You can excuſe a Fault too well, not to have been to blame—A ready Anſwer ſhews you were prepar'd.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Guilt is ever at a loſs, and Confuſion waits upon it; when Innocence and bold Truth are always ready for Expreſſion—

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: Not in Love; Words are the weak Support of cold Indifference; Love has no Language to be heard.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Exceſs of Joy has made me ſtupid! Thus may my Lips be ever clos'd. (Kiſſes her.) And thus—Oh who would not loſe his Speech, upon Condition to have Joys above it?

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: Hold, let me lock the Door firſt.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: (Aſide.) That I believ'd; 'twas well I left the private Paſſage open.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: So, that's ſafe.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: And ſo may all your Pleaſures be, and ſecret as this Kiſs—

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: And may all Treachery be thus diſcover'd.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Villain!

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Nay then, there's but one Way.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Say you ſo, were you provided for an Eſcape? Hold, Madam, you have no more Holes to your Burrough, I'll ſtand between you and this Sally-Port.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: Thunder ſtrike thee dead for this Deceit, immediate Lightning blaſt thee, me and the whole World—Oh! I could rack my ſelf, play the Vulture to my own Heart, and gnaw it piece-meal, for not boding to me this Misfortune.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Be Patient.—

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: Be Damn'd.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Conſider I have you on the Hook; you will but flounder your ſelf a weary, and be nevertheleſs my Priſoner.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: I'll hold my Breath and die, but I'll be free.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: O Madam, have a care of dying unprepar'd, I doubt you have ſome unrepented Sins that may hang heavy, and retard your Flight.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: O! what ſhall I do? ſay? Whither ſhall I turn? Has Hell no Remedy?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: None, Hell has ſerv'd you ev'n as Heav'n has done, left you to your ſelf.—You're in a kind of Eraſmus Paradice; yet if you pleaſe you may make it a Purgatory; and with a little Penance and my Abſolution all this may turn to good Account.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Hold in my Paſſion, and fall, fall a little thou ſwelling Heart; let me have ſome intermiſſion of this Rage, and one Minute's Coolneſs to diſſemble.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: You have been to blame.—I like thoſe Tears, and hope they are of the pureſt Kind—Penitential Tears.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p:
O the Scene was ſhifted quick before me—I had not time to think—I was ſurpriſed to ſee a Monſter in the Glaſs, and now I find it is my ſelf; Can you have Mercy to forgive the Faults I have imagined, but never put in practice—Oconſider, conſider
how fatal you have been to me, you have already kill'd the Quiet of this Life. The Love of you, was the firſt wand'ring Fire that e'er miſs-led my Steps, and while I had only that in View, I was betray'd into unthought of Ways of Ruin.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: May I believe this true?

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: O be not cruelly incredulous—How can you doubt theſe ſtreaming Eyes? Keep the ſevereſt Eye o'er all my future Conduct; and if I once relapſe, let me not hope Forgiveneſs, 'twill ever be in your Power to ruin me—My Lord ſhall ſign to your Deſires; I will my ſelf create your Happineſs, and Cynthia ſhall be this Night your Bride—Do but conceal my Failings, and forgive.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Upon ſuch Terms I will be ever yours in ev'ry honeſt Way.

div.stage: Enter Lord Touchwood, Maskwell ſoftly behind him.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I have kept my Word, he's here, but I muſt not be ſeen.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Hell and Amazement, ſhe's in Tears.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: (Kneeling) Eternal Bleſſings thank you—Ha! My Lord liſt'ning! O Fortune has o'erpaid me all, all! all's my own! [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Nay, I beſeech you riſe.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: (Aloud.) Never, never! I'll grow to the Ground, be buried quick beneath it, e'er I'll be conſenting to ſo damn'd a Sin as Inceſt! unnatural Inceſt!

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: O cruel Man, will you not let me go—I'll forgive all that's paſt—O Heav'n, you will not Raviſh me!

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Damnation!

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Monſter, Dog! your Life ſhall anſwer this—
sp.stage: [Draws, and runs at Mel. is held by Lady Touch.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: O Heav'ns my Lord! Hold, hold, for Heav'ns ſake.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Confuſion, my Uncle! O the damn'd Sorcereſs.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: Moderate your Rage, good my Lord! He's mad, alas he's mad—Indeed he is my Lord, and knows not what he does—See how wild he looks.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: By Heav'n 'twere ſenſeleſsſs not to be mad, and ſee ſuch Witchcraft.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: My Lord, you hear him, he talks idly.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Hence from my Sight, thou living Infamy to my Name; when next I ſee that Face, I'll write Villain in't with my Sword's Point.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Now, by my Soul, I will not go 'till I have made known my Wrongs—Nay, 'till I have made known yours, which (if poſſible) are greater—though ſhe has all the Hoſt of Hell her Servants; though ſhe can wear more Shapes in ſhining Day, then Fear ſhews Cowards in the Dark—

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: Alas he raves! Talks very Poetry! For Heav'ns ſake away my Lord, he'll either tempt you to Extravagance, or commit ſome himſelf.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Death and Furies, will you not hear me—Why by Heav'n ſhe laughs, grins, points to your Back; ſhe forks out Cuckoldom with her Fingers, and you're running Horn-mad after your Fortune.
sp.stage: [As ſhe is going ſhe turns back and ſmiles at him.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: I fear he's mad indeed—Let's ſend Maskwell to him.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Send him to her.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: Come, come, good my Lord, my Heart akes ſo, I ſhall faint if I ſtay.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: O I could curſe my Stars, Fate, and Chance; all Cauſes and Accidents of Fortune in this Life! But to what purpoſe? Yet, 'ſdeath, for a Man to have the Fruit of all his Induſtry grow full and ripe, ready to drop into his Mouth, and juſt when he holds out his Hand to gather it, to have a ſudden Whirlwind come, tear up Tree and all, and bear away the very Root and Foundation of his Hopes; What Temper can contain? They talk of ſending Maskwell to me; I never had more need of him—But what can he do? Imagination cannot form a fairer and more plauſible Deſign than this of his which has miſcarried.—O my precious Aunt, I ſhall never thrive without I deal with the Devil, or another Woman.
sp.l: Women like Flames have a deſtroving Pow'r,
Ne'er to be quench'd, 'till they themſelves devour.

div.head: ACT V. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: WAſt not Lucky?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Lucky! Fortune is your own, and 'tis her Intereſt ſo to be; By Heav'n I believe you can controul her Pow'r, and ſhe fears it; though Chance brought my Lord, 'twas your own Art that turn'd it to Advantage.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: 'Tis true it might have been my Ruin—But yonder's my Lord, I believe he's coming to find you, I'll not be ſeen.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: So; I durſt not own my introducing my Lord, though it ſucceeded well for her, for ſhe would have ſuſpected a Deſign which I ſhould have been puzzled to excuſe. My Lord is thoughtful—I'll be ſo to; yet he ſhall know my Thoughts; or think he does—

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: What have I done?

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Talking to himſelf!

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: 'Twas honeſt—and ſhall I be rewarded for it? No, 'twas honeſt therefore I ſhan't;—Nay, rather therefore I ought not for it rewards it ſelf.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: Unequall'd Virtue! [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: But ſhould it be known! then I have loſt a Friend! He was an ill Man, and I have gain'd for half my ſelf I lent him, and that I have recall'd; ſo I have ſerved my ſelf, and what is yet better, I have ſerved a worthy Lord to whom I owe my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Excellent Man! [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Yet I am wretched—O there is a Secret burns within this Breaſt, which ſhould it once blaze ſorth, would ruin all, conſume my honeſt Character, and brand me with the name of Villam.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p:
Why do I love! Yet Heav'n and my waking Conſcience are my Witneſſes, I never gave one working Thought a vent; which might diſcover that I lov'd, nor ever muſt; no, let it prey upon my Heart; for I would rather die, than ſeem once, barely ſeem, diſhoneſt:—O, ſhould it once be known I love fair Cynthia, all this that I have done would look like Rival's Malice, falſe Friendſhip to my Lord, and baſe Self-intereſt. Let me periſh
firſt, and from this Hour avoid all Sight and Speech, and, if I can, all Thought of that pernicious Beauty. Ha! But what is my Diſtraction doing? I am wildly talking to my ſelf, and ſome ill Chance might have directed malicious Ears this way.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Start not—let guilty and diſhoneſt Souls ſtart at the Revelation of their Thoughts, but be thou fix'd, as is thy Virtue.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I am confounded and beg your Lordſhip's Pardon for thoſe free Diſcourſes which I have had with my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Come, I beg your Pardon that I over-heard you, and yet it ſhall not need—Honeſt Maskwell! thy and my good Genius led me hither—Mine, in that I have diſcover'd ſo much manly Virtue; thine, in that thou ſhalt have due Reward of all thy Worth. Give me thy Hand—my Nephew is the alone remaining Branch of all our ancient Family; him I thus blow away, and conſtitute thee in his room to be my Heir—

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Now Heav'n forbid—

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: No more—I have reſolv'd—The Writings are ready drawn, and wanted nothing but to be ſign'd, and have his Name inſerted—Yours will fill the Blank as well—I will have no Reply—Let me command this time; for 'tis the laſt, in which I will aſſume Authority—hereafter, you ſhall rule where I have Power.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I humbly would petition—

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Is't for your ſelf?— [Mask. pauſes.] I'll hear of nought for any body elſe.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Then Witneſs Heav'n for me, this Wealth and Honour was not of my ſeeking, nor would I build my Fortune on another's Ruin: I had but one Deſire—

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt enjoy it—If all I'm worth in Wealth or Intereſt can purchaſe Cynthia, ſhe is thine.—I'm ſure Sir Paul's Conſent will follow Fortune; I'll quickly ſhow him which way that is going.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: You oppreſs me with Bounty; my Gratitude is weak, and ſhrinks beneath the Weight, and cannot riſe to thank you—What, enjoy my Love! Forgive the Tranſports of a Bleſſing ſo unexpected, ſo unhop'd for, ſo unthought of!

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: I will confirm it, and rejoice with thee.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p:
This is proſp'rous indeed—Why let him find me out a Villain ſettled in Poſſeſſion of a fair Eſtate, and full Fruition of my Love, I'll bear the Railings of a loſing Gameſter—But ſhou'd he find me out before! 'tis dangerous to delay—Let me
think—ſhou'd my Lord proceed to treat openly of my Marriage with Cynthia, all muſt be diſcover'd, and Mellefont can be no longer blinded.—It muſt not be; nay, ſhou'd my Lady know it—ay, then were fine Work indeed! Her Fury wou'd ſpare nothing, tho' ſhe involv'd her ſelf in Ruin. No, it muſt be by Stratagem—I muſt deceive Mellefont once more, and get my Lord to conſent to my private Management. He comes opportunely—Now will I, in my old way, diſcover the whole and real truth of the Matter to him, that he may not ſuſpect one Word on't.
sp.l: No Mask like open Truth to cover Lies,
As to go Naked is the beſt Diſguiſe.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: O Maskwell, what Hopes? I am confounded in a maze of Thoughts, each leading into one another, and all ending in Perplexity. My Uncle will not ſee, nor hear me.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: No matter, Sir, don't trouble your Head, all's in my Power.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: How? For Heav'ns ſake?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Little do you think that your Aunt has kept her Word,—How the Devil ſhe wrought my Lord into this Dotage, I know not; but he's gone to Sir Paul about my Marriage with Cynthia, and has appointed me his Heir.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: The Devil he has! What's to be done?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I have it, it muſt be by Stratagem; for it's in vain to make Application to him. I think I have that in my Head that cannot fail: Where's Cynthia?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: In the Garden.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Let us go and conſult her, my Life for yours, I cheat my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: Maskwell your Heir, and marry Cynthia!

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: I cannot do too much, for ſo much Merit.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: But this is a thing of too great Moment to be ſo ſuddenly reſolv'd. Why Cynthia? Why muſt he be Married? Is there not Reward enough in raiſing his low Fortune, but he muſt mix his Blood with mine, and wed my Niece? How know you that my Brother will conſent, or ſhe? Nay, he himſelf perhaps may have Affections otherwhere.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: No, I am convinc'd he loves her.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: Maskwell love Cynthia, impoſſible!

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: I told you, he confeſs'd it to me.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: Confuſion! How's this! [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: His Humility long ſtifled his Paſſion: And his Love of Mellefont would have made him ſtill conceal it.—But by Encouragement, I wrung the Secret from him; and know he's no way to be rewarded but in her. I'll defer my farther Proceedings in it, 'till you have conſider'd it; but remember how we are both indebted to him.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: Both indebted to him! Yes, we are both indebted to him, if you knew all, damn'd Villain! Oh, I am wild with this Surprize of Treachery: Hell and Fire, it is impoſſible, it cannot be.—He Love Cynthia! What have I been Bawd to his Deſigns, his Property only, a baiting Place to ſtay his Stomach in the Road to her; now I ſee what made him falſe to Mellefont,—Shame and Deſtruction! I cannot bear it, oh! what Woman can bear to be a Property? To be kindled to a Flame, only to light him to another's Arms; oh! that I were Fire indeed, that I might burn the vile Traitor to a Hell of Torments,—But he's Damnation proof, a Devil already, and Fire is his Element. What ſhall I do? How ſhall I think? I cannot think,—All my Deſigns are loſt, my Love unſated, my Revenge unfiniſh'd, and freſh cauſe of Fury from unthought of Plagues.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Madam, Siſter, my Lady Siſter, did you ſee my Lady my Wife?

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: Oh! Torture!

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Gad's-bud, I can't find her high nor low; where can ſhe be, think you?

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: Where ſhe's ſerving you, as your Sex ought to be ſerv'd; making you a Beaſt. Don't you know that you're a Fool, Brother?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: A Fool; he, he, he, you're merry—No, no, not I, I know no ſuch matter.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: Why then you don't know half your Happineſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: That's a Jeſt with all my Heart, faith and troth,—But harkee, my Lord told me ſomething of a Revolution of things; I don't know what to make on't,—Gad's-bud I muſt conſult my Wife,—he talks of diſinheriting his Nephew; and I don't know what,—Look you, Siſter, I muſt know what my Girl has to truſt to; or nor a Syllable of a Wedding, gad's-bud—to ſhew you that I am not a Fool.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p:
Hear me; conſent to the breaking off this Marriage, and the promoting any other, without conſulting me, and I'll renounce
all Blood, all Relation and Concern with you for ever,—nay, I'll be your Enemy, and purſue you to Deſtruction, I'll tear your Eyes out, and tread you under my Feet.—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter now? Good Lord, what's all this for? Pooh, here's a Joke indeed—Why, where's my Wife?

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: With Careleſs, in the cloſe Arbour; he may want you by this time, as much as you want her.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: O, if ſhe be with Mr. Careleſs, 'tis well enough.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: Fool, Sot, inſenſible Ox! But remember what I ſaid to you, or you had better eat your Horns, and pimp for your Living; by this Light you had.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: She's a paſſionate Woman, gads-bud,—But to ſay truth, all our Family are Cholerick; I am the only peaceable Perſon amongſt 'em.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I know no other Way but this he has propos'd; if you have Love enough to run the Venture.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: I don't know whether I have Love enough,—but I find I have Obſtinacy enough to purſue whatever I have once reſolv'd; and a true Female Courage to oppoſe any thing that reſiſts my Will, tho' 'twere Reaſon it ſelf.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: That's right,—Well, I'll ſecure the Writings, and run the Hazard along with you.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: But how can the Coach and Six Horſes be got ready without Suſpicion?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Leave it to my Care; that ſhall be ſo far from being ſuſpected, that it ſhall be got ready by my Lord's own Order.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Why, I intend to tell my Lord the whole matter of our Contrivance, that's my way.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I don't underſtand you.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Why, I'll tell my Lord, I laid this Plot with you, on purpoſe to betray you; and that which put me upon it, was, the finding it impoſſible to gain the Lady any other way, but in the Hopes of her Marrying you.—

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: So—

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: So, why ſo, while you're buſied in making your ſelf ready, I'll wheedle her into the Coach; and inſtead of you, borrow my Lord's Chaplain, and ſo run away with her my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: O I conceive you, you'll tell him ſo?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Tell him ſo! Ay, why you don't think I mean to do ſo?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: No, no; ha, ha, I dare ſwear thou wilt not.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: (Aſide.) You may be deceiv'd.—Therefore for our farther Security, I would have you diſguis'd like a Parſon, that if my Lord ſhould have Curioſity to peep, he may not diſcover you in the Coach, but think the Cheat is carried on as he would have it.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Excellent Maskwell, thou wert certainly meant for a Stateſman or a Jeſuite, but that thou art too honeſt for one, and too pious for the other.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Well, get your ſelves ready, and meet me in half an Hour, yonder in my Lady's Dreſſing-Room; go by the back Stairs, and ſo we may ſlip down without being obſerv'd.—I'll ſend the Chaplain to you with his Robes; I have made him my own,—and ordered him to meet us to Morrow Morning at St. Albans; there we will ſum up this Account, to all our Satisfactions.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Should I begin to thank or praiſe thee, I ſhould waſte the little time we have.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Madam, you will be ready?

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: I will be punctual to the Minute.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Stay, I have a doubt—Upon ſecond Thoughts, we had better meet in the Chaplain's Chamber here, the corner Chamber at this end of the Gallery, there is a back Way into it, ſo that you need not come through this Door—and a Pair of private Stairs leads down to the Stables—It will be more convenient.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: I am guided by you,—but Mellefont will miſtake.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: No, no, I'll after him immediately, and tell him.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: I will not fail.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Why, qui vult decipi decipiatur.—'Tis no Fault of mine, I have told 'em in plain Terms, how eaſie 'tis for me to cheat 'em; and if they will not hear the Serpent's Hiſs, they muſt be ſtung into Experience, and future Caution.—Now to prepare my Lord to conſent to this.—But firſt I muſt inſtruct my little Levite; there is no Plot, publick or private, that can expect to proſper without one of 'em has a Finger in't, he promiſed me to be within at this Hour,—Mr. Saygrace, Mr. Saygrace.
sp.stage: [Goes to the Chamber Door, and knocks.

sp.speaker: Mr. Saygrace,
sp.p: (looking out.) Sweet Sir, I will but pen the laſt Line of an Acroſtick, and be with you in the twinkling of an Ejaculation, in the pronouncing of an Amen, or before you can—

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Nay, good Mr. Saygrace do not prolong the Time, by deſcribing to me the ſhortneſs of you Stay; rather if you pleaſe, defer the finiſhing of your Wit, and let us talk about our Buſineſs, it ſhall be 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Sayg.
sp.p: (Enters) You ſhall prevail, I would break off in the middle of a Sermon to do you pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: You could not do me a greater,—except—the Buſineſs in hand—Have you provided a Habit for Mellefont?

sp.speaker: Sayg.
sp.p: I have, they are ready in my Chamber, together with a clean ſtarch'd Band and Cuffs.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Good, let them be carried to him,—have you ſtitch'd the Gown Sleeve, that he may be puzzled, and waſte time in putting it on?

sp.speaker: Sayg.
sp.p: I have; the Gown will not be indued without Perplexity.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Meet me in half an Hour, here in your own Chamber. When Cynthia comes, let there be no Light, and do not ſpeak, that ſhe may not diſtinguiſh you from Mellefont. I'll urge haſte, to excuſe your Silence.

sp.speaker: Sayg.
sp.p: You have no more Commands?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: None, your Text is ſhort.

sp.speaker: Sayg.
sp.p: But pithy, and I will handle it with Diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: It will be the firſt you have ſo ſerv'd.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Sure I was born to be controlled by thoſe I ſhould Command: My very Slaves will ſhortly give me Rules how I ſhall govern them.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I am concern'd to ſee your Lordſhip diſcompos'd.—

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Have you ſeen my Wife lately, or diſoblig'd her?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: No, my Lord. What can this mean! [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Then Mellefont has urg'd ſome body to incenſe her—Something ſhe has heard of you which carries her beyond the Bounds of Patience.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: This I fear'd. (Aſide.) Did not your Lordſhip tell her of the Honours you deſign'd me?

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: 'Tis that; you know my Lady has a high Spirit, ſhe thinks I am unworthy.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Unworthy! 'Tis an ignorant Pride in her to think ſo—Honeſty to me is true Nobility. However, 'tis my Will it ſhould be ſo, and that ſhou'd be convincing to her as much as Reaſon—By Heav'n, I'll not be Wife-ridden; were it poſſible, it ſhould be done this Night.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: By Heav'n he meets my Wiſhes. (Aſide.) Few Things are impoſſible to willing Minds.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Inſtruct me how this may be done, you ſhall ſee I want no Inclination.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I had laid a ſmall Deſign for to Morrow (as Love will be inventing) which I thought to communicate to your Lordſhip—But it may be as well done to Night.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Here's Company—Come this way, and tell me.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Is not that he, now gone out with my Lord?

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: By Heav'n there's Treachery—The Confuſion that I ſaw your Father in, my Lady Touchwood's Paſſion, with what imperfectly I over-heard between my Lord and her, confirm me in my Fears. Where's Mellefont?

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Here he comes.
Did Maskwell tell you any thing of the Chaplain's Chamber?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: No; my Dear, will you get ready—the Things are all in my Chamber; I want nothing but the Habit.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: You are betray'd, and Maskwell is the Villain I always thought him.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: When you were gone, he ſaid his Mind was chang'd, and bid me meet him in the Chaplain's Room, pretending immediately to follow you, and give you notice.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: There's Saygrace tripping by with a Bundle under his Arm—He cannot be ignorant that Maskwell means to uſe his Chamber; let's follow and examine him.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: 'Tis loſs of time—I cannot think him falſe.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: My Lord muſing!

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: He has a quick Invention, if this were ſuddenly deſign'd—Yet he ſays he had prepar'd my Chaplain already.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: How's this! Now I fear indeed.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Cynthia here! alone, fair Couſin, and melancholy?

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip was thoughtful.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: My Thoughts were on ſerious Buſineſs, not worth your Hearing.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Mine were on Treachery concerning you, and may be worth your Hearing.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Treachery concerning me! pray be plain—Hark! What Noiſe!

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: (within) Will you not hear me?

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: (within) No, Monſter! Helliſh Traitor! No.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: My Lady and Maskwell! this may be lucky—My Lord, let me intreat you to ſtand behind this Skreen, and liſten; perhaps this Chance may give you proof of what you ne'er could have believ'd from my Suſpicions.

div.stage: Enter Lady Touchwood with a Dagger, Maskwell.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: You want but Leiſure to invent freſh Falſhood, and ſooth me to a fond Belief of all your Fictions; but I will ſtab the Lie that's forming in your Heart, and ſave a Sin, in pity to your Soul.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Strike then—Since you will have it ſo.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: Ha! A ſteady Villain to the laſt!

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Come, why do you dally with me thus?

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: Thy ſtubborn Temper ſhocks me, and you knew it would—By Heav'n, this is Cunning all, and not Courage; no, I know thee well: But thou ſhalt miſs thy Aim.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: Ha! Do you mock my Rage? Then this ſhall puniſh your fond, raſh Contempt! Again Smile!

And ſuch a Smile as ſpeaks in Ambiguity! Ten thouſand Meanings lurk in each Corner of that various Face. O! That they were written in thy Heart, That I, with this, might lay thee open to my Sight! But then 'twill be too late to know—

Thou haſt, thou haſt found the only way to turn my Rage; Too well thou know'ſt my jealous Soul cou'd never bear Uncertainty. Speak then, and tell me—Yet are you ſilent? Oh, I am wilder'd in all Paſſions! But thus my Anger melts. (Weeps) Here, take this Ponyard, for my very Spirits faint, and I want Strength to hold it, thou haſt diſarm'd my Soul.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Amazement ſhakes me—Where will this end?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: So, 'tis well—let your wild Fury have a Vent; and when you have Temper, tell me.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: Now, now now I am calm, and can hear you.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Thanks, my Invention; and now I have it for you.—Firſt tell me what urg'd you to this Violence? For your Paſſion broke in ſuch imperfect Terms, that yet I am to learn the Cauſe.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: My Lord himſelf ſurpriz'd me with the News, you were to marry Cynthia—That you had own'd your Love to him, and his Indulgence would aſſiſt you to attain your Ends.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: How, my Lord!

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Pray forbear all Reſentments for a while, and let us hear the reſt.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I grant you in Appearance all is true; I ſeem'd conſenting to my Lord; nay, tranſported with the Bleſſing—But could you think that I who had been happy in your lov'd Embraces, could e'er be fond of an inferior Slavery.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Ha! O Poiſon to my Ears! What do I hear!

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Nay, good my Lord, forbear Reſentment, let us hear it out.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Yes, I will contain, tho' I cou'd burſt.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I that had wanton'd in the wide Circle of your World of Love, cou'd be confin'd within the puny Province of a Girl. No—Yet tho' I dote on each laſt Favour more than all the reſt; though I would give a Limb for every Look you cheaply throw away on any other Object of your Love; yet ſo far I prize your Pleaſures o'er own, that all this ſeeming Plot that I have laid, has been to gratifie your Taſte, and cheat the World, to prove a faithful Rogue to you.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: If this were true—But how can it be?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I have ſo contriv'd, that Mellefont will preſently, in the Chaplain's Habit, wait for Cynthia in your Dreſſing-Room: But I have put the Change upon her, that ſhe may be otherwhere employ'd—Do you procure her Night-Gown, and with your Hoods tyed over your Face, meet him in her ſtead; you may go privately by the back Stairs, and, unperceiv'd, there you may propoſe to reinſtate him in his Uncle's Favour, if he'll comply with your Deſires; his Caſe is deſperate, and I believe he'll yield to any Conditions,—If not, here take this; you may employ it better, than in the Death of one who is nothing when not yours.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: Thou can'ſt deceive every Body,—Nay, thou haſt deceiv'd me; but 'tis as I would wiſh,—Truſty Villain! I could worſhip thee.—

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: No more,—There wants but a few Minutes of the time; and Mellefont's Love will carry him there before his Hour.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: I go, I fly, incomparable Maskwell!

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: So, this was a Pinch indeed, my Invention was upon the Rack; and made Diſcovery of her laſt Plot: I hope Cynthia and my Chaplain will be ready, I'll prepare for the Expedition.

div.stage: Cynthia, and Lord Touchwood, come forward.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Now, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p:
Aſtoniſhment binds up my Rage! Villany upon Villany! Heav'ns, what a long Track of dark Deceit has this diſcover'd! I am confounded when I look back, and want a Clue to guide
me through the various Mazes of unheard of Treachery. My Wife! Damnation! my Hell!

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: My Lord, have Patience, and be ſenſible how great our Happineſs is, that this Diſcovery was not made too late.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: I thank you, yet it may be ſtill too late, if we don't preſently prevent the Execution of their Plots;—Ha, I'll do't. Where's Mellefont, my poor injur'd Nephew,—How ſhall I make him ample Satisfaction?—

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: I dare anſwer for him.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: I do him freſh Wrong to queſtion his Forgiveneſs; for I know him to be all Goodneſs,—Yet my Wife! Dam her,—She'll think to meet him in that Dreſſing-Room,—Was't not ſo? And Maskwell will expect you in the Chaplain's Chamber,—For once, I'll add my Plot too,—let us haſte to find out, and inform my Nephew; and do you, quickly as you can, bring all the Company into this Gallery.—I'll expoſe the Strumpet, and the Villain.

div.stage: Enter Ld. Froth and Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Ld. F.
sp.p: By Heav'ns I have ſlept an Age,—Sir Paul, what a Clock is't? Paſt Eight, on my Conſcience, my Lady's is the moſt inviting Couch; and a Slumber there, is the prettieſt Amuſement! But where's all the Company?—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: The Company, gads-bud, I don't know, my Lord, but here's the ſtrangeſt Revolution, all turn'd topſie turvy; as I hope for Providence.

sp.speaker: Ld. F.
sp.p: O Heav'ns, what's the matter? Where's my Wife?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: All turn'd topſie turvy, as ſure as a Gun.

sp.speaker: Ld F.
sp.p: How do you mean? My Wife!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: The ſtrangeſt Poſture of Affairs!

sp.speaker: Ld. F.
sp.p: What, my Wife?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: No, no, I mean the Family,—Your Lady's Affairs may be in a very good Poſture; I ſaw her go into the Garden with Mr. Brisk.

sp.speaker: Ld. F.
sp.p: How? where, when, what to do?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe they have been laying their Heads together.

sp.speaker: Ld. F.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Nay, only about Poetry, I ſuppoſe, my Lord; making Couplets.

sp.speaker: Ld. F.
sp.p: Couplets.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: O, here they come.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: My Lord, your humble Servant; Sir Paul yours,— 〈…〉

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: My Dear, Mr. Brisk and I have been Star-gazing, I don't know how long.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Does it not tire your Ladyſhip? are not you weary with looking up?

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: Oh, no, I love it violently,—My Dear, you're melancholly.

sp.speaker: Ld. F.
sp.p: No, my Dear; I'm but juſt awake.—

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: Snuff ſome of my Spirit of Hartshorn.

sp.speaker: Ld. F.
sp.p: I've ſome of my own, thank you, my Dear.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: Well, I ſwear, Mr. Brisk, you underſtood Aſtronomy like an old Egyptian.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Not comparable to your Ladyſhip; you are the very Cynthia of the Skies, and Queen of Stars.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: That's becauſe I have no Light, but what's by Reflection from you, who are the Sun.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Madam, you have Eclips'd me quite, let me periſh,—I can't anſwer that.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: No matter,—Hark'ee, ſhall you and I make an Almanack together.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: With all my Soul,—Your Ladyſhip has made me the Man in't already, I'm ſo full of the Wounds which you have given.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: O finely taken! I ſwear now you are even with me, O Parnaſſus, you have an infinite deal of Wit.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: So he has, gads-bud, and ſo has your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: You tell me moſt ſurprizing things; bleſs me, who would ever truſt a Man? O my Heart akes for fear they ſhould be all deceitful alike.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: You need not fear, Madam, you have Charms to fix Inconſtancy it ſelf.

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: O dear, you make me bluſh.

sp.speaker: Ld. F.
sp.p: Come, my Dear, ſhall we take leave of my Lord and Lady?

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: They'll wait upon your Lordſhip preſently.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: Mr. Brisk, my Coach ſhall ſet you down.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: What's the matter?
sp.stage: [A great Shriek from the Corner of the Stage. Lady Touchwood runs out affrighted, my Lord after her, like a Parſon.

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: O I'm betray'd.—Save me, help me.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Now what Evaſion, Strumpet?

sp.speaker: L. T.
sp.p: Stand off, let me go, and Plagues and Curſes ſeize you all.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Go, and thy own Infamy purſue thee.—You ſtare as you were all amazed,—I don't wonder at it,—but too ſoon you'll know mine, and that Woman's Shame.

div.stage: Enter Mellefont lugging in Maskwell from the other ſide of the Stage, Mellefont like a Parſon.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Nay, by Heav'n you ſhall be ſeen.—Careleſs, your Hand;—Do you hold down your Head? Yes, I am your Chaplain, look in the Face of your injur'd Friend; thou Wonder of all Falſhood.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Are you ſilent, Monſter?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Good Heav'ns! How I believ'd and lov'd this Man!—Take him hence, for he's a Diſeaſe to my Sight.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Secure that manifold Villain.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Miracle of Ingratitude!
sp.stage: [They carry out Maskwell, who hangs down his Head.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: This is all very ſurprizing, let me periſh

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: You know I told you Saturn look'd a little more angry than uſual.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: We'll think of Puniſhment at Leiſure, but let me haſten to do Juſtice, in rewarding Virtue and wrong'd Innocence.—Nephew, I hope I have your Pardon, and Cynthia's.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: We are your Lordſhip's Creatures.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: And be each others Comfort;—Let me join your Hands.—Unwearied Nights, and wiſhing Days attend you both; mutual Love, laſting Health, and circling Joys, tread round each happy Year of your long Lives.
sp.l: Let ſecret Villany from hence be warn'd;
Howe'er in private Miſchiefs are conceiv'd,
Torture and Shame attend their open Birth:
Like Vipers in the Womb, baſe Treachery lies,
Still gnawing that, whence firſt it did ariſe;
No ſooner born, but the Vile Parent dies.

div.head: EPILOGUE,
div.l: COuld Poets but foreſee how Plays would take,
Then they could tell what Epilogues to make;
Whether to thank or blame their Audience moſt:
But that late Knowledge does much Hazard coſt,
'Till Dice are thrown, there's nothing won, nor loſt.
So 'till the Thief has ſtoll'n, he cannot know
Whether he ſhall eſcape the Law, or no.
But Poets run much greater Hazards far,
Than they who ſtand their Trials at the Barr;
The Law provides a Curb for its own Fury,
And ſuffers Judges to direct the Jury.
But in this Court, what Diff'rence does appear!
For every one's both Judge and Jury here;
Nay, and what's worſe, an Executioner.
All have a Right and Title to ſome Part,
Each chuſing that in which he has moſt Art.
The dreadful Men of Learning all Confound,
Unleſs the Fable's good, and Moral ſound.
The Vizor-Masks, that are in Pit and Gallery,
Approve, or Damn, the Repartee and Rallery.
The Lady Criticks, who are better read,
Enquire if Characters are nicely bred;
If the ſoft things are penn'd and ſpoke with Grace:
They Judge of Action too, and Time, and Place;
In which we do not doubt but they're diſcerning,
For that's a kind of Aſſignation Learning.
Beaus judge of Dreſs; the Witlings judge of Songs;
The Cuckoldom, of Ancient Right, to Cits belongs.
Thus poor Poets, the Favour are deny'd,
Even to make Exceptions, when they're Try'd.
'Tis hard that they muſt ev'ry one admit;
Methinks I ſee ſome Faces in the Pit,
Which muſt of Conſequence be Foes to Wit.
You who can Judge, to Sentence may proceed;
But tho' he cannot Write, let him be freed
At leaſt from their Contempt, who cannot Read.
